WRITING.TITLE: Market Hero - auto responder platform
WRITING.TEXT: I run an expansion of an accounting business. As you can imagine, this is our busiest time of the year, but my firm has not had a decent email marketing apparatus in place. I have been looking for a way to use sales funnels to market our services, and came across Market Hero on a few YouTube videos and posts. Online reviews seem to be split - and I can't tell who is an affiliate marketer with obvious bias in what they say about the product, and who is just sour grapes (from the detractors) because they either don't really understand how to use the platform or affiliate market for a competitors product. I was hoping someone here had experience with Market Hero and could tell me what they thought.

Nope. Not what I said. I think in the wild that's a totally rational and valid way of handling this, but we are not there. Laws, society, etc. (If it wasn't for those, then you're on the money. If it wasn't for our social contract / experiment, he should absolutely beat his ex-roommate to within an inch of his life so no one else catches on to how easy he is to use and how willing he is to let stuff get taken from him. If he didn't, he'd be easy prey.) But, and here's YOUR leeway, hopefully he does have a job and a future. His image - let's be real - that's not worth protecting, because it's weak. And he's choosing to keep to that image because it's easier than changing. The problem with your method here is that even when they did "talk" he couldn't stand up for himself. He lacks the fundamental basic self-respect to set a boundary and enforce it. You have a guy who values his own wants, needs, and health so poorly that he was willing to lie about them so he wouldn't rock the boat. He's repressing very real and very valid negative feelings to his own detriment. In fact, we KNOW he was lying because he cried himself to sleep. Does that sound like open and honest communication to you? Or is it someone trying play off how 'mature' and 'understanding' they are? So he doesn't have to admit how angry he is, how sad he is, and how hurt he is, bringing his shame out into the open. That crying fit was caused by shame. And he SHOULD feel shame. Because that shame was the one little part of himself that he's pushing way down that's saying he is not okay with this and wants to change. Shame, like all pain, is stimulus for action. Do not praise this guy - you are taking away a very real chance for him to fix himself. By praising him you are denying someone a REAL opportunity to mature into a healthy adult.

WRITING.TITLE: What can be done about the sway the left and far left hold over universities?
WRITING.TEXT: One of the more troubling things I #8217;ve witnessed in my lifetime was the virtual disappearance of right leaning voices from American college campuses. At my undergrad, the college republicans were dwarfed by the other side easily 1:10. Granted, this was a small, affluent liberal arts college - but it was in the south. Professors routinely taught liberal ideology and opinion as fact, denigrated opposing viewpoints in class, and generally gave little attention to anything that came from a conservative source. Outside of Econ classes and a few political science classes- that was my experience. What can be done in the coming years to bring balance to the American undergraduate experience?

In traffic, your average moron sees 1000 feet in front of the truck as open space they can weave in and out of. Hell, half the time the non commercial driver merges into a trucker #8217;s lane and hits the brakes- because massive moving vehicles pulling ridiculous weights are known for stopping on a dime and maneuverability. Just two examples of #8220;truckers killing people #8221; that do not warrant continual government harassment, unless you want the literal lifeblood of the economy to come to a screeching halt. The movie itself was okay. Honestly the action was good from a visual perspective, the dialogue was meh, and while I thought the character was fairly badass as far as superheroines go, her character #8217;s background lacked true depth to really connect. I mean there was supposed to be this hardship she faced but really it wasn #8217;t all that dramatic or even beyond what your average person deals with in the course of their life: people telling you you can #8217;t do something or you can #8217;t cut it. Literally anyone that is successful hoes through that. Granted, the film portrays this as a result of being a tomboyish girl, but it #8217;s kinda like - big deal. My little sister faced way worse on her rise through sports and overcame way worse. I admire her much more than captain marvel. I also think they drastically overpowered the character as some sort of statement. She flies through entire battleships and tears them apart like butter. At no point did I ever think she wasn #8217;t going to win. It #8217;s really the same gripe I have with Superman, except Superman #8217;s backstory and archetype actually give him a depth of character. Overall, it was like Rey from star wars except with less of a connecting backstory. Not saying I hated it, I can separate idiotic things actors and actresses say from their characters, and I #8217;m not going to be brainwashed by a poorly told story, but I #8217;m not saying it was the worst thing I #8217;ve ever seen.

First, raise your prices. If you are still swamped in a couple months, hire a part time employee. Get swamped again? Raise prices. Still? Another employee. Get to three employees and three price raises. At that point, evaluate your employees - is there one that #8217;s a natural leader? Do they have the qualities you want and can you trust them? Let them know you want to watch them closely for the next month or something like that - if they are who you hope they are, congrats, that #8217;s your new #8220;foreman #8221; / your replacement. You don #8217;t go out anymore. Now your job is to manage their jobs and work on your marketing. Get really into your finances and customer service. Work on making the jobs more efficient. Monitor their performance closely. When you can, get additional trucks / employees. When you begin to tap out or plateau, look for possible additional services or pivots. Expand. Your previous aspects of your job - financials, efficiency management, marketing, customer service? Look to outsource those as well. Keep the stuff you genuinely like to do. Have weekly and monthly meetings with your people so you dont lose touch. From there, shit I don #8217;t know. I #8217;ve only ever grown businesses to that point. This is just a loose summary and sounds loads easier than it actually is, but it IS a gameplan.

Not really. Extrapolate. Our globalized economy is cutthroat and is - by necessity - a macro free market. If inefficiency in timing or allocation exists it is exploited to the inefficiency holder #8217;s detriment, either through outside state groups or through more competitive economies removing that inefficiency. Example is say is the US cannot offer the best price or best product on something needed in say Nigeria. The Nigerians will then field other offers for the same and then China, or Singapore fills that need. The US economy then takes a hit while the void filler sees an uptick. Repeat ad nauseum and your country goes broke. Edit: plus we can #8217;t crunch actuals here unless there is a state utilizing this economic model. Are there?

WRITING.TITLE: Advice on short term career strategy
WRITING.TEXT: Hello! Looking for advice and thoughts here. I have a legal background and picked up some finance chops along the way. After a business I started ended up failing (thankfully not due to my own faults but industry-wide issues and a poor partner relationship) I interviewed for and got a job as a Financial Analyst at a very large company - Tier 1 supplier. Originally I interviewed as an account financial manager, and was offered the role. HR then came in and screwed me over a bit, but used my lack of financial history in my resume to ding me down to the FA level. I took the job because it #8217;s a huge opportunity to pivot careers and grow a skill set, not to mention I #8217;m working under extremely knowledgeable people - all of whom I respect and get along well with. I have been utterly killing it. Started projects that have ended up becoming standardized on a company wide level and my work ends up in front of the CFO monthly now. I even took on the account financial manager role for accounts that were left without one after people left. Now I #8217;m looking at short to medium term career advancement strategy. I have been told I will most likely get the promotion to what I was originally brought in for, but the salary won #8217;t fall within what I was promised before HR interfered. Also, the company appears to be stagnating and pulling in purse strings - people aren #8217;t getting raises or promotions they deserve. My dilemma: I want to get above the 110k compensation level as quickly as possible. It #8217;s a large jump from where I #8217;m at now. Am I better off taking a promotion in title and a 10% pay bump and biding my time / looking to jump to another company or am I better off asking for a title promotion up two grades, settling for the ~7% I think I #8217;m likely to get and then in another year using that title to leverage a much higher compensation level at another company - possibly getting to my 110K goal? There #8217;s a lot more, but I think this is a good basic level of info. Any thoughts are welcome and appreciated!

If consulting is your goal then it #8217;s worth it. Self-investment is always a great get in terms of ROI - but you need to consider opportunity cost. If you own a business, if you have other investments you can make, etc. That might be a bit vague by way of summary, but that #8217;s the way I look at it. I #8217;m not going into consulting but if I want to reach higher levels within my industry then I need an MBA for when HR evaluates my resume / pedigree.

(Keep in mind I #8217;m speaking specifically from my industry) while a check the box MBA might provide some benefit and it would meet that Hr requirement, it #8217;s only going to get me so far. A check the box would get me put into a leadership position on a cross-functional team. Good money, good responsibility. But if I ever want to see C-Suite before I #8217;m in my late 50s, I have to get a more prestigious program on my CV. For me, that #8217;s most likely Ross or Booth. Of all the MBAs I work with, those with check the box are solid middle to upper middle management levels. Those that went to Ross, HBS, MIT, and the one guy that got his from Yale - they #8217;re all department heads, VPs, or C-Suite. I don #8217;t know if their reach was due to natural skill or the network they had access to or what- but I #8217;d be willing to say that the organization puts a premium on those MBAs.

WRITING.TITLE: 203k, house hacking, and business case analysis
WRITING.TEXT: I #8217;ve worked with a wholesaler for a little while but own none of my own properties. As I have a great shot at an FHA I began looking at properties around my market - Detroit metro area. Having recently learned about the 203K and Michigan #8217;s MSHDA - (https://www.michigan.gov/mshda/0,4641,7-141-45866_45868-370762--,00.html)I #8217;ve become very interested in buying, rehabbing, and renting / house hacking a property as opposed to just setting up a deal. Problem is I am having difficulty putting together a decently thorough business case analysis for a 203k property or a 203k property with the MSHDA. Does anyone have any advice, considerations, details, or even a business case analysis they #8217;d be able to share?

By metro I mean outlying cities- places like Ferndale, Royal Oak, Plymouth, Northville, Birmingham. So not exactly downtown Detroit. Places I #8217;m looking to invest aren #8217;t in downtown area either- more like B and C neighborhoods.
